moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5: Even today this is the most common variant of the King's Gambit Accepted.
moves.6. Bc4 d5 7. exd5 Bd6 8. O-O: This move [8 O-O] makes it a Rice Gambit. Like all variants of the KGA, it is a risky but very exciting line to use as White.
moves.8... Bxe5 9. Re1 Qe7 10. c3 Bf5 11. d4: White opens up lines for the Q-side pieces while attacking the pinned B.
moves.13... fxe6 14. dxe6 O-O-O: Now Black makes a daring piece sacrifice instead of simply moving the Knight. Back then Chess players had pluck! There were a lot fewer draws and a lot more sacrificial attacks.
moves.15. exd7+ Rxd7 16. Qe2 Qxh4: Black has gained two Pawns in return for the piece and has 3 pieces aimed ominously at White's King.
moves.19. Nd2 Rxd2: Sacrificing an Exchange to remove a defender and increase the pressure.
moves.20. Bxd2 Qh2+ 21. Kf1 f3: With Black threatening to close the ring, White initiates a counteroffensive, beginning a series of checks.
moves.22. Qa8+ Kd7 23. Qa4+ c6 24. Re7+: White's countersacrifice drives the Black King into the open center of the board, away from the shelter of the Q-side Pawns.
Now White can pick up the Rook with tempo.
moves.28. Qe5+ Ka8 29. Qxh8+ Ka7 30. Qd4+ b6: White's string of checks has bought him time to get his King away from the danger zone on the K-side.
moves.32... c5 33. Qe5 g1=Q+: Winning back the piece via promotion.
moves.36... g2 37. Qe7+ Kb8 38. Qe3: Black resigns, as the Pawn cannot now successfully promote.

players: Emanuel Lasker + Allies  vs. David Janowski + Allies
